title.narrative: Equipping the Next Generation of INnovative biological Engineers to develop disease diagnostics for Africa (BioENGINE Africa STAR)

description.narrative: Equipping the Next Generation of INnovative biological Engineers to develop disease diagnostics for Africa (BioENGINE Africa STAR)

The aim of BioENGINE Africa is to introduce synthetic biology research skills training into universities in Ghana, Cameroon and Kenya offering graduate-level courses in engineering or biotechnology. This will underpin demand for these skills both in academic research and in the rapidly growing bioeconomy sector that is a strategic priority for the African Union. Synthetic biology offers rich interdisciplinary educational opportunities at the intersection of chemistry, biology, engineering, computer science and design. We aim to equip researchers across disciplines with essential skills to meet real-world challenges through adoption of engineering approaches such as design, build and test cycles to the development of diagnostics for local priorities in human, animal, plant and environmental health. Objectives 1. To identify and establish a cohort of 12 talented lecturers from Ghana, Cameroon and Kenya who actively teach graduate-level courses in engineering or biotechnology and are motivated and able to incorporate synthetic biology skills training into their institutional teaching with the support of their cohort peers and the UK participants, who have a long track record in supporting educational initiatives in synthetic biology. 2. To train the cohort in the use of effective pedagogies for synthetic biology education, specifically the application of “Design, Build, Test” engineering cycle to biological systems and next generation biotechnologies. 3. To mentor and support the cohort in their professional development and facilitate the delivery of research skills training in synthetic biology to over 150 graduate students. 4. To design teaching resources including practicals that are meaningful and incorporate inquiry-led learning opportunities but are also affordable and feasible to provide on a continuing basis in resource-constrained institutions. We will share these resources openly for all who wish to use them. 5. To support the incorporation of BioENGINE Africa modules into Masters and PhD programmes at the participating institutes and support the lecturer cohort in advocating for further provision of synthetic biology research skills at national curriculum level, aligned with local and international bioeconomy strategies. 6. To inspire and inform researchers who will apply the skills they acquire through the courses to developing impactful diagnostics whether in the partner countries or through applying to international opportunities.
